review.title: Beyond OWL 2 QL in OBDA: Rewritings and Approximations (Extended Version)
review.abstract: Ontology-based data access (OBDA) is a novel paradigm facilitating access to relational data, realized by linking data sources to an ontology by means of declarative mappings. DL-Lite_R, the current language of choice for OBDA, has been designed with the goal of delegating query answering to the underlying database engine, and thus is restricted in expressive power. E.g., it does not allow one to express disjunctive information, and any form of recursion on the data. The aim of this paper is to overcome these limitations of DL-Lite_R, and extend OBDA to more expressive ontology languages, while still leveraging the underlying relational technology for query answering. We achieve this by relying on two well-known mechanisms, namely conservative rewriting and approximation, but significantly extend their practical impact by bringing into the picture the mapping, an essential component of OBDA. Specifically, we develop techniques to rewrite OBDA specifications with an expressive ontology to "equivalent" ones with a DL-Lite_R ontology, if possible, and to approximate them otherwise. We do so by exploiting the high expressive power of the mapping layer to capture part of the domain semantics of rich ontology languages. We have implemented our techniques making use of a state-of-the-art OBDA system, and we have shown their feasibility and effectiveness with experiments on synthetic and real-world data.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Ontology based on data access (OBDA) is a popular paradigm that allows end-users to access data sources through an ontology that abstracts the details of the data sources themselves. Ontology provides a high-level description of the area of interest and is semantically linked to the data sources through a series of mapping assertions (Calvanese et al. 2009; Giese et al. 2015). Typically, data sources are presented as relational data, ontology is constituted by a series of logical axioms about concepts and roles, and each mapping assertion refers to an SQL query through the database to a concept or role of ontology. As an example, we consider a bank domain in which we can specify that a verification account in a person's name is a simple account that is cist by means of the axiom (expressed in the description of logical notation) accounts.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: We proposed a novel framework to reformulate and approximate the OBDA specifications in an expressive ontology language to the OBDA specifications in a weaker language, in which the basic idea is to use the mapping layer to encode part of the semantics of the original OBDA specification, and we developed techniques for DL-LiteR as the target language. We intend to extend our technique to Horn SHIQ and, more generally, to Datalog rewritable TBoxes (Cuenca Grau et al. 2013). In addition, we will deepen our understanding of the computational complexity when deciding on the CQ rewritability of OBDA specifications in DLLiteR. We also plan to conduct more comprehensive experiments, taking into account queries containing existentially quantified variables, which will allow us to review the effectiveness of RewDA as the objects were specifically designed for handling implicit.
